name: The Plan
description: A fly ascends to the skies, pondering the pointlessness of its brief existence. The Plan was developed as a side project by Krillbite Studio, who's currently finishing their main project Among the Sleep."Hey, You Should Play This" - Patrick Klepek, Giantbomb"Some may argue that The Plan isn't really a game and it...

reviews.review_text: This is probably one of the shortest 'games' on Steam; it lasts only 5 to 10 minutes, and then it's finished. Many would argue it's not a 'game', since there is almost no gameplay. In  The Plan  you are a fly, a fly with a plan. She wants to fly higher than any fly has ever done before, so she starts on a journey of discovery. You can lead the fly a bit during her journey, but in the end she goes up and up and up, and that's it as far as playing this game is concerned.  But arguing if  The Plan  should be called a game or not, is besides the point. For me, it's like a small but polished piece of art. If large and great games like  Middle Earth: Shadow or Mordor  are the novels of games, then  The Plan  is an exquisite poem, maybe even as short as a Japanese Haiku. It's all about atmosphere, and about the gradual changes in atmosphere as the journey progresses. These shifts are made through the artwork, and also through the soundscape. In the beginning there's not much more than the sound of the fly up-close, but once she soars higher, the developers with a stroke of genius added a piece out of Edvard Griegs hauntingly beautiful music for Ibsens play  Peer Gynt : 'Aases Tod'. The emotional effect of this sudden musical layer took me by surprise, and made a deep impact. There are even many more 'layers' to be discovered, but just as in any good poem, these should be left to the player's imagination.  So, just get this one, and treat yourself on a special journey. It's free, so don't object ;-).  Overall score: 9/10

The Plan is not a game, It's rather short interactive experience. It will take you only few minutes to finish it. As I see, for many people this game is something more than just a simple experience. It gives them some kind of mystical experience, even reveals the secret of life. It didn't give me so much. To be honest I was little bored of it. So why did I give it positive review? Because after all it turned out to a nice joke and I enjoyed it.  VERDICT: It's free and it takes only about 5 minutes, so you have nothing to lose. Maybe you will find secret of life here or maybe you will laugh at the end. Or maybe you will be disappointed, who knows? But even in the worst situation you will listen to very nice music.  It's worth to find out.  Like this review? This will be an odd review, as it might take longer to read this post than the 5 minutes the game took to play through.  The Plan happens to be a wonderful take on the brevity of life and how well it can be shown in such brevity- through the life of a fly. Sure, there might be arguments over the validity of calling this a 'game,' but it doesn't really matter. It's a short and controlled experience that brings you on a journey of struggle and insight about your place in the universe and what meaning we may find in what little time we get to live for.  This game has all it needs to make a great game, pared down to the absolute minimums necessary. A pervading and eerie atmosphere, subtly haunting music, and the smallest story about the path of life itself. We try to ascend as much as possible in the time we are given and therein lies the transcendent reflection on the nature of life.

Gotta say I was pretty skeptical and wary of just how 'good' this experience would be, given how 'amazing' other pretentious artsy indie games were. I mean; it's about a fly. But figured that for free and for something that was apparently so short it was worth a shot anyway. Even if I do have a bit of a bug phobia and actually wondered if I could handle 5 minutes of nothing but a fly.  Well... it's a good thing I didn't let any of that get to me. I wasn't prepared for just how impactful this game would become. First Aase's Death starts playing followed by an unexpected increased visual range and scope. The further you go the music builds and the visual journey becomes more epic until... the end. That's it. It's done in a flash. It gave me chills and made me tear up and then it was done and I just sat in silence for a moment as I pondered what I just experienced. It was so unexpectedly moving and really just plain unexpected in general. Such as life, which this 'game' portrays quite uniquely well in more ways than one.  Really... great things really can come in small packages. Even ones not at first visually appealing. See, this is what I meant about it being such a simple, yet eloquently conveyed metaphor on life. The Plan can be taken in any number of ways and can vary slightly in meaning and depth from person to person, making it more worthwhile to take five to ten minutes out of your day to play this little 'game' through once or twice respectively and see what you make of it.  ______________________________________________ Easter egg: Click the credits at the start after beating the game. :D
The Plan provides a brief, divine glimpse into the life of a fly. That's all it does, and that's all it needs to do. Recommended.

I decided to try it. what i got wasnt a laugh, wasnt a scream, but an experience. Im not gonna lie. I cried in the game. Its just so touching. A small game that provokes a million thoughts. I feel ashamed of played with this game free. This game is a true masterpiece. 10/10

The story about the obstacles in a flies daily life.  I personally really enjoyed flying around in The Plan.  The atmosphere was beautiful, the music fitted in perfectly and the story was very touching. It's not really a 'Game' its more of an experience you go through.

More of an experience - a short one - than a game, but delivers exactly as promised.  I guess what you get out of this, is going to be relative to what you put into it. I found it to be food for thought on a number of topics so it is interesting enough for me, even just for this reason  But I also find the graphics to be sweet, soundtrack to be one of zero-annoyance, and the ending was effective and well-placed to avoid monotony - and can add a new spin to your musings.  Replayability - well it is a kind of story without much ability to control it so once you have seen it, any replayability will come down to whether you will get more thought from re-experiencing it, and that is subjective - I will keep the game in my account because I would like to see what I get from it, or put into it, upon replay at some time.   And I did not feel that the price was unreasonable :)   I would recommend this as a short experience that may inspire some reflections, and I will be interested to see what more interactive and immersive creations the devs come up with.
I do feel like I have more insight into ... the meaning of life.

This game just touched me in a way I couldn't comprehend. This game, by itself, has made me question the purpose of my existence. In fact, it made me question why we ALL exist. It's symbolic of both hell and heaven. 'Is The Plan a great game?' No, it isn't. It's the best damn game that you can possibly view upon and play. Do yourself a favor, and enlighten yourself with this masterpiece.

If you want an actual game, don't download this.  That said, it's artsy, pretty, and quick.  But the real reason to download this is because in ten minutes time you can get the one and only achievement and add a 'Perfect Game' to your profile.  To do this, beat the game, click the restart, then click the little credits that pop up at the start this time. It's that simple.

The Plan is truly the greatest and most inspirational game of our era. No game has invoked so many emotions and so much philosophical thought in me. It has opened endless avenues regarding the meaning of all that is around us, which all games have failed to do; until The Plan came along  You play as a quiet but determined fly as you try to transcend the airs of wisdom and try to discover the meaning of the universe. This truly masterful game starts you off at the bottom where you appear beaten and defeated. Fear not however; as you aren't ready to give up yet. You will be able to fly and navigate through the roughest terrain and beautiful scenery as you try to fly to the top and become one with the universe, gaining its infinite knowledge. When you reach the top, the phenomenal writing throws you a twist that none could have foreseen. The ending will give players a completely different perspective on everything that they might have known.   The graphics and sountrack are perfect as well, with a tear-jerking song playing halfway through this masterpiece. No games have ever reached the graphical fidelity as The Plan has. If all games were held to the sound and graphical standards of The Plan, we would be living in a gaming utopia.  The Plan is one of those games that no one will ever forget its greatness. Whether it is the flawless writing, the beautiful sound, the awe-inspiring graphics, or the fantastic gameplay, The Plan is going down into the history books as the most revolutionary and inspirational game that will ever be.
The best FPS i have ever played.

A beautifully tailored masterpiece depicting Man's struggle against the ever-cruel world we sad humans reside in... I demand a sequel to this unforgettable journey of a lifetime. Why traverse the stars when you can sit down on your dirty desk chair, load this wonderful work of pure genius and explore the galaxy with the common house fly? Special thanks to my friend Jon Hoseman for recommending me this experience of a lifetime. The simple yet intricate 5 minute journey brought me to a different time and realm, allowing to ponder life's gifts. It is a pity Mother Nature had not granted the common housefly sentience, else the human race be doomed. thank you, The Plan, you have opened my eyes...

Simple, short, thoughtful (in a profoundly Ecclesiastes-like, meaningless way), and pretty.  An easy achievement, if that's what you're looking for:  1.) Click on the fly to start 2.) Fly UP and avoid the few minor hazards 3.)   Fly into the light   4.) Click reset at game end to return to the start screen 5.) Click the credits at screen bottom to earn achieve  My game crashed the first time I clicked the credits, but it processed after a restart - 1 achieve, 100%, ~5 minutes.  If you're wondering, after the fly turns into the glowbug there is no new content for repeating the game, at least for a single repeat through.

In over 25 years experience in games, nothing has surprised as has 'The Plan.' Behind its simple, yet elegant facade of a Fly's flight to freedom lies a stirring tale of identity, guilt, and self discovery, all with a simple, but beautiful, underlying question which pervades every aspect of this experience: Why? I got through it in one sitting, glued to my chair. It brought me through an emotional roller coaster, all culminating in a heartbreaking finale that left me in tears. Not only is this without question the best video game, it is the most extraodinary creative feat I have ever had the great pleasure of experiencing.

The Plan  is not a game, but a small piece of interactive freeware. The eerie, yet beautiful background along with the fitting soundtrack and simple mechanics provide players with a soothing five minute playthrough.

This game is by far one of the best 2D upward scrolling six-minute fly simulators on Steam. It offers immersive slowly hovering gameplay, while 4 arrow keys offer a wide range of intensely complex controls and unnatural vertical flight patterns. Truly, this game's defining characteristic is its unparelleled storyline, keeping users enthralled up to the very end, when the sudden plot twist gives them insight as to what it really means to be one of the most boring and inconsequential organisms on the entire planet. Perhaps the best feature is the notable lack of lag and small download size for low-end PCs. A must have for anyone with no money and a heavily refurbished and cobbled together 2003 Windows XP computer.

This is as far the most realistic fly simulator I've ever played. We can feel the 6-minutes worth of flying around with the burning sensation of flying around reaching the most final goal, the light. It is a very long game, and I truly enjoy the game. The game itself gives us the feels, and lets us know how it feels to be a fly, and how to be a wise fly. The sound of the environment, the sound of the fly's wings, they combine altogether and make a wonderful melody. Flying leaves, and standing trees, doesn't let the fly to give up. I love this game to the very end. This game is very educational, I'd recommend this for everyone who is looking for games.   This is definitely the best game I've ever seen. With this game, I've learned, and I won't kill flies anymore, I know how they feel very well, and it indeed hurts. I cried, I knew this would happen. I feel sorry for them. Going through the obstacles of avoiding people to live on their own, trying hard to reach the goal. Flies are the most wonderful living being I've ever seen, the God's creature, just like us, who deserves life just like any other creatures in the universe. 11/10 I would play it over and over. Thanks, The Plan, you've brightened the light of the people who plays your game.

The fly has a limited perception when compared to ours and our ability to quantify and calculate the universe. To the fly our perception of reality would be mind blowing to say the least. The laws of the universe we have come to, 'understand' can and only have been proven through our 5 senses. They cannot be proven any further because we cannot take an objective look, and if we did.. what other senses would we need to be able to ultilize to get a true objectlive look at reality. Our perception of the universe is as flawed as the the perception the fly carries through this game and ultimately.. to his death.

Life of Fly   My journey starts out with me on my humble home the rock(or was that poop), a spike of curiosity suddenly welled up in me saying 'hey lets fly up, up as far as the light that always shone above us.'  Thus my journey began, my journey started out easy, just the leaves falling and falling but suddenly I got caught by a spiderweb. 'No, my journey must not end now, I have yet to reach the light far above the sky', I struggled to escape from death, I though all hope was lost but the strings of the web grew loose and each one unhinging from their roots I became free.  Continuing my journey, sudden gusts of winds blew through, each of the gales it blew I struggled to go forth... the light is near, I must endure... the winds grew stronger and stronger but I did not let myself be stopped, my goal is almost at a palms reach.  At last the winds subsided and I flew even higher, higher than any fly would've dared, but what is this, am I in space or am I in heaven? The view was breathtaking, there were lights everywhere, clouds that formed magnificently but that is not the best site, for beyond that was a glowing red orb, was this my creator? or was it the sun. I couldn't possibly know how far I have flown. It shown beautifully, I must reach for it... a horrifying sound was made as I touched it, I couldn't see anything... everything was black but then as sudden as the darkness, light came in, a blinking line asked for my name so I gave it what it asked, I must have entered heaven...   10/10  This game made me live a life I will never forget

It's not so much a 'game' in the traditional sense - sure it has controls, but the six minutes that it takes to complete the game are a fantastic example of voiceless storytelling in video games.  Spoilers Follow:  You are a fly. You use the WASD or Arrow keys to fly around. At first, it seems a little bit pointless. There are no Quick TIme Events, no onscreen objectives, and a relativly sparse world that doesn't really have any interactive areas. So you just fly across, until you hit an invisible wall, then you begin to fly upward. The soundtrack simmers. A gust of wind hits you, ushering you across to another invisible wall. You can only continue up.  Reaching a wide expanse of space, you continue upward. It worked before, right? The orchestral soundtrack swells as god rays appear, guiding you upward, as if toward some form of salvation. The light gets brighter, and an opaque object appears. Could it be...?  White screen. It was a lightbulb.  A blinking cursor appears. You stare at it. What will it type? A profound philisophical quote from Socrates? A nihlist insight revelant to modern society? No, nothing comes up. The cursor blinks, again and again. Then it hits you.   you   are meant to type something.  You are the overseerer of what happens next. In fact, you controlled the fly to the pre-determined end that it met. The gusts of wind, the invisible walls - they might have served a purpose in game design, but they were also indicitive of another concept; The inevitability of life, and the misconception of having control in our ultimate destination.  The fly is destined to die - we led it there, but apart from leaving our keyboard, there was no other end goal. In this way, we don't feel bad about killing something; we have been given no backstory about the fly, or any reason to control it. We just did so out of past conditioning to control. And when we saw the lightbulb, we continued towards it, knowing the fly would be destroyed, and the game would be over. The comment being made by the developers is one about our subconcious acknowledgment of fate being pre-determined, and our primal desires to control the destinies of others, no matter how logically or logistically viable that might be.   I guess the main point is that six minutes of shooting a fly into a lightbulb has made me learn more about my self than 600 hours in Skyrim or Borderlands 2. Just play the damn thing - it will take you less time than it took to read this diatribe.  Score: As a game, 5/10. As a statement, 10/10.

I'll start off by saying that this game will have very split reactions among its players. Some will call it a unique, haunting metaphor for our mortality and life. Others will write this game off as too simple, devoid of any meaning or substance, and too artsy-fartsy. After playing this game, I can see why both camps would believe these things.  Admittedly, there isn't much to this game. You are a fly, and you decide to fly higher and higher... and that's all I'll say about the plot. I wouldn't be able to tell much more beyond that without spoiling the game anyway, seeing as you can complete the game within 5 to 10 minutes.   However, a game's length doesn't completely determine if a game is good or not. How much you enjoy the game should be mostly dependent on the player's overall experience. Yes, length can be a big factor in one's enjoyment, but some games are designed to be short, one-and-done playthroughs.  The Plan  is the embodiment of this philosophy. It doesn't matter that the game can be finished in roughly 1/5th of an hour; as long as the player enjoyed their brief time as a fly, then time is irrelevant in this case.  Players may be divided when it comes to the overall gameplay of The Plan, but it's hard to deny that a lot of effort went into detailing this game. The graphics look quite nice, with mostly dark backgrounds that reminded me of LIMBO or NightSky. However, while those games mostly had silhouetted landscapes, The Plan has a bit more detail. Gusts of wind are drawn on-screen smoothly, giant leaves threaten to crush the philosophical fly, and the game's climax shocks us with a surprising transition or two.  I must also tip my hat to whoever was in charge of the audio for this game, as it is simply some of the best ambient noise I've ever heard. Rustling leaves, huge wind gusts, a tense encounter in the trees, and the haunting melody in the finale stand out in my mind long after I finished playing. The sound quality in this game is superb, and I was completely immersed in this game due to how realistic the sounds were.  As I mentioned above, the game is incredibly short, so there is very little to no replayability once you've seen the conclusion, since you know what happens. The game also seems to crash at the end of the game when returning to the main menu (as of the time of this writing), and, for whatever reason, I can't figure out why there is a text field after the conclusion. But these are some minor gripes. They don't detract at all from the game's overall quality.  In conclusion, I recommend you play this game if you want to do a bit of thinking about morality and regret, need a quick time-waster (and want to earn a quick achievement), or if you just want to hear a haunting tune. And, at a low price of free, you have nothing to lose if you don't like it (well, other than 5 minutes of your time, but aren't we all wasting time anyway?).  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------   Pros:    + Great atmosphere + Nice visuals + Amazing sounds + Thought-provoking + Doesn't drag itself out too long / feels like the perfect length for a casual game + FREE!    Cons:    - Game has virtually no replayability after the ending - Crashes when returning to main menu (at the time of this writing)

Some people have made the mistake of seeing Killbrite Studio's work as a load of rubbish about flies, but clever people like me, who talk loudly in restaurants, see this as a deliberate ambiguity, a plea for understanding in a mechanized world. The points are frozen, the beast is dead. What is the difference? What indeed is the point? The point is frozen, the beast is late out of Paddington. The point is taken. If La Fontaine's elk would spurn Tom Jones the engine must be our head, the dining car our esophagus, the guard's van our left lung, the cattle truck our shins, the first-class compartment the piece of skin at the nape of the neck and the level crossing an electric elk called Simon. The clarity is devastating. But where is the ambiguity? It's over there in a box. Shunt is saying the 8:15 from Gillingham when in reality he means the 8:13 from Gillingham. The train is the same only the time is altered. Ecce homo, ergo elk. La Fontaine knew his sister and knew her bloody well. The point is taken, the beast is moulting, the fluff gets up your nose. The illusion is complete; it is reality, the reality is illusion and the ambiguity is the only truth. But is the truth, as Hitchcock observes, in the box? No there isn't room, the ambiguity has put on weight. The point is taken, the elk is dead, the beast stops at Swindon, Chabrol stops at nothing, I'm having treatment and La Fontaine can get knotted.

'What then is truth? A movable host of metaphors, metonymies, and anthropomorphisms: in short, a sum of human relations which have been poetically and rhetorically intensified, transferred, and embellished, and which, after long usage, seem to a people to be fixed, canonical, and binding. The Plan is a game, but not a game. It is a philosophical adventure, where a fly explores the meaning of life, the meaning of existence, the meaning of the universe. The Plan will make you doubt yourself, and how you have lived your life. The Plan of the fly is to unveil truths, and to make players philosophize. The Plan will make you wonder, 'Who am I to this fly?'  A quick little quest, not replayable, but beautiful.

It's up to you to decide what you learn from this game. Some may not see anything and think this game wasted 4-6 minutes of his/her life playing this game. Some may learn an important lesson from this game.

I played 10 minutes or so of The Plan before I reached the ending (or so it would seem). I made a concerted effort not to rush through the game, just tried to explore it.  The game is not very substantial, and it is very short. The Plan is ultimately a game made on the side by developers who are working on a bigger game, and I would not expect much more.  However, what it lacks in quantity it makes up for in quality. The Plan is a very aesthetically pleasing game, easy to run and is enjoyable to play. There is no combat or puzzle solving, just the pure exploration of the imagination of the game's creators. The music is excellent and really adds a feeling of immersion. Such a game would not be expected to have much of a replay value, but what it does have is heart and a lovely idea.  For the very generous price of absolutely nothing, I see no reason why not to devote a few minutes of your day to pick up this little beaut.

Jacob's Story Read below to read about his epic journy of hardship and beauty to reach the stars!!  ***SPOILER ALERT***         Since Jacob was a little larvae he had a dream that he would go on a great adventure to the great beyond and fly away with the wind. When he turn 20 days old he grew the courage to leave and begin on his epic adventure. It was a dangerous trek from all dangers. Furious, gushing winds. Gigantic leaves falling off from trees. When he finally flew above the trees, he gasped of how breathe taking the stars and sky were. He flew higher and higher, trying to reach the stars. As he was flying higher he imagined his self flying to the stars. He thought to himself that he would fly farther than the stars.....to the moon. He wanted to look down and see the whole world. He flew faster and faster to reach the sky. Jacob saw a bright light above the sky. 'Is that the sun?' he said in excitement. He flew closer and closer to it as it grew bigger and bigger. As he flew closer to it, he could feel the bright heat coming off of it. His eyes determined on the light he flew closer. Jacob felt determined that he just needed to touch it. ....And he could, He flew to it, hugging and feeling its warm embrace. Then.....zzzzZZZAAAAAPPPPPP!!!!!!! As Jacob was falling downward, he looked to bright light and saw the stars and the clouds and the moon. Gazing upon their beauty, he felt that he lived his life with no regrets. He smiled, as his wing broke away from his burnt body. A tear came to his eye as the sky turned to dark and engalfed by the tall trees. He closed his eyes to imagine himself flying through the stars as he hit the ground. He saw the bright light once more and felt nothing.....and felt everything.  Jacob was still young, but he followed his dreams to the end. He embraced the massive world and took it head on. He will always be remembered and loved. We will miss him.   R.I.P. Jacob 8/2/2015-8/21/2015

Maybe I'm just insensitive, because I'm not seeing where the appeal is coming from. The music is nice, the visuals are nice, but it isn't life changing by any means. I guess the appeal comes from the lesson, which funnily enough could be anything. That life will have hurdles, and no matter what you do you'll die in the end? That flies have thoughts, no matter how miniscule, yet are disregarded so heavily?  In the end, I just can't grasp the appeal except that in the end, what you type is displayed. Which has given me chuckles, seeing people put 360noscope among other things. You get what you pay for, which isn't much more than a self-determined lesson (one that you probably already knew, no less) and some laughs when you see what other people wrote.

Edited 20 Jan 2015  Coming back to this after nearly a year and the ending made me smile. Did I change as a person in that year? Am I more easily amused? I don't know but it did raise a smile....

I don't think The Plan is a game in the traditional sense. It's not even fun in the traditional sense. But it has meaning. It's a story. Even if the story is (very) open to interpetation, it instils feelings in the player. Which, if you think about it, is what games are all about.  It's hard to delve into what the game is about without spoiling it, so I'll try to be vague. In The Plan, you play as a fly in a big, scary world. You work hard to keep pushing forward, rising from your place on the forest floor up into the heavens, only to find that the heavens aren't what you think. The 'twist' at the end is small, but still speaks volumes towards the idea that this glorious, awe-inspiring ascension is more grounded than it appears at first.   The Plan is very, very short. A single playthrough might last 10 minutes at the most. It is possible that, for some, it may take longer to download this game than to play through it. Despite its puny length, The Plan is definitely worth a look. The game looks great visually, and the soundtrack is absolutely glorious. Unless you are some hotshot banker, on-call heart surgeon, or someone else whose time is super important, The Plan is worth the 10 minutes and $0 you will spend on it.
A short allegory of life told through the many eyes of a fly. Music and lighting work together to create a beautiful atmospheric effect. A remarkable tale of a game.

My take away of The Plan is that it is a brief experiential metaphor on the journey through life. It begins with curiousity and wonder then takes you through the complacent routine, sudden hazards and obstacles, beauty and contemplation, and ultimately an almost comedic tragedy. The Plan is visually and audibly beautiful with a stylistic visuals and a soundtrack that compliment each other and the experience as a whole. It is the gaming equivalent of a masterful short story or film short, and well worth the 5 minutes or so it takes you to complete it.

I never know whether to reccomend or discourage when it comes to free to play games, because it's not like you can ask for your money back. For what it's worth, The Plan does look quite nice, but even to a pretentious indiephile such as myself I see little point in this game. Some of the art assets look lovely, and the ending is a bit of a shock, but I think this game was going for a kind of simple poigniancy that I'm afraid it doesn't quite achieve. Perhaps it's due to the fact that they used poorly made 3D sprites in occasions where it would've been simpler and more attractive to use 2D ones, perhaps it's due to the lack of player involvement, and the original idea could've been worked into something a bit more engaging, but as it stands, Plan still falls short somehow.

'A fly ascends to the skies, pondering the pointlessness of its brief existence.' Everyone should play through The Plan atleast once. This game is a great expirience that words can't describe. The Plan is the most beautiful game I have ever played. You start as a fly near the ground and ascend upwards. The fly encounters some dangers ( wind, leaves, and a spiderweb ) and eventually is over the tree tops. At the end you are flying high in the sky and can see stars in the background. A large light appears above you and eventually your fly is attracted to a lightbulb. When the fly touches the lightbulb ( mysteriously sitting in the sky ) the screen turns white. You are given the option to type whatever you want on the white screen. The Plan will make you ponder life and existence. Enjoy.

Life. In one game.   Sometimes, it may seem that there's nothing in your way as you ascend up in life. Other times, it may only take a single leaf to take you down. Occasionally, you might be weak enough only for a gust of wind to sweep you off your feet, but if you believe you're strong enough, you will be able to conquer that gust of wind. Spider webs, you can't get away from these. You will get stuck, you will get shocked, and you will know fear. Only in these times, though, you will know your strength.  There always comes a point in time, where there's nothing in your way. Once you reach this point, you begin to believe you have reached what you have strived for. But as you ascend up, up, into the sky that is life, you begin to realize that to everything, there is an end.  8 minutes on record. I do not regret those 8 minutes of my life spent on this game, and those minutes I spent to write this.  Life. In one game.  Definitely recommended.

A fly, thats what you are. A simple, pointless existence...oh wait, you are trying to fly upward while avoiding being crushed by leaves, fighting powerful wind currents, and worst of all, every flys worst nightmare come to reality...spiderwebs. An amazing game with amazing artwork and detail, the plan is exactly that, a plan to get to the very top, no matter what could possibly stand in your way, you must go where no fly ever dared to go before. This game is truly amazing, and i personally do not care what all the haters say, this game is short, yes, but truly amazing in it's own right. A truly awe-inspiring experience.

What to say about the plan...hmmmmm. It was truly a masterpiece in the videogame world. If you are going to play any fly simulator this year, make it the plan. The background music and the scenery adds to the intensity of the game, no the experience of a lifetime. Plus, an end that will leave you in shivers. I really connected with the main character, I felt like I was actually the fly, trying to figure out my meaning in life. I highly recommend this perfectly crafted game. You will not be disappointed. The plan will always hold a place in my heart in the video game world.

The Plan seems more art than game and its premise is very simple. You are a fly whos only goal is to reach the great bright light in the sky. Keep flying past falling leaves, wind gusts, and spider webs as you elegantly weave through the tree canopy. If you want to get deep you can find meaning in the game hinting towards the futility of life and the dissatisfaction with reaching to attain lofty goals, or you can just appreciate that this free game has a single achievement that you can complete in about 5 minutes.  I do recommend using some sort of surround sound headphones as the soundtrack and effects are great.

'The Plan' is an art house installation on your PC.  It is a textured work that needs to be experienced and interpreted by the viewer rather than explained by a third party.  What I will say though is that what you get out of this may be nothing other than boredom. You may, if a little more atuned, feel an appreciation of the exquisite graphics and soaring, perfectly suited sounds. However, you may, if you are in the right frame of mind experience something much more.   It's all down to you.  Life is just a cosmic joke afterall.... but it's up to you to write the punchline.

At first glance, this game appears to be a fly simulator, or something. But, as I played this game, I noticed things about it that make it generate profound thought.  As you progress as the fly, the camera zooms farther out, making you less significant on the screen. This is symbolic of how insignificant we become when we see how much of the world operates without care of our existance. As we see more of the world, it becomes easier to realize how insignificant each one of us truly is. As we realize our own insignificance, we draw nearer to the light of truth (embodied within the game as the light bulb), and eventually, we reach it.  Okay, maybe I'm off in left field somewhere, but that's what I took away from the game.

Download it.  This was exactly what i needed. I was going through some anxiety and decided to try this out... i needed something simple. Basically all you need to know is the art design is great.. evocative and moody. The sound effects great. The sinlge musical score that guides you to the game's end is utterly beautiful. And no spoils... but a great ending. The game is very short as you have probably noticed... so i recommend to play this when you really need it. When you are feeling down... just click start... the second it begins it will hook you until its all over... i feel a lot better now
It was very atmospheric and calming, but also gave me anxiety XD

This game shows that 'meaning' is something we invent. Just persist and see for yourself.  On hindsight, I'm laughing because this is the only game in the world that makes you 'feel' something for a creature you'd otherwise swat away. Atmosphere, music, visuals - they come together quite nicely.
Perfect.
